definitions.definition: to think something or have an opinion about something

examples.text: I reckon (that) I’m going to get that job.
He'll be famous one day. **What do you reckon** *(= do you agree)*?
It's worth a lot of money, I reckon.
‘They'll never find out.’ ‘**You reckon?**’ *(= I think you may be wrong about that)*

definitions.definition: to be generally considered to be something
definitions.sensetop: be reckoned to be/have something+ noun/adj.

examples.text: Children are reckoned to be more sophisticated nowadays.
It was generally reckoned a success.
We reckon to finish by ten.
He wasn’t reckoning to pay so much.

definitions.definition: to calculate an amount, a number, etc.
definitions.sensetop: reckon somethingbe reckoned at somethingreckon (that)…it is reckoned that…be reckoned to do something

examples.text: I could see him reckoning the cost as I spoke.
The age of the earth is reckoned at about 4.6 billion years.
They reckon (that) their profits are down by at least 20%.
It is generally reckoned that about half of all job vacancies are never advertised publicly.
The journey was reckoned to take about two hours.
The trip was reckoned to take over two days.

definitions.definition: a person or thing that is well known and respected in a particular field

examples.text: Miyazaki is still a name to conjure with among anime fans.

definitions.definition: used when you mention a name that you think is difficult to remember or pronounce

examples.text: He comes from Tighnabruaich—now there's a name to conjure with!

definitions.definition: a person or thing that is well known and respected in a particular field

examples.text: Miyazaki is still a name to reckon with among anime fans.

wordOrigin: Old English (ge)recenian ‘recount, relate’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch rekenen and German rechnen ‘to count (up)’. Early senses included ‘give an account of items received’ and ‘mention things in order’, which gave rise to the notion of “calculation” and hence of “being of an opinion”.
